comments.commentBody: Senator Warren often appears as a special pleader for the education industry.  See her positions on ed loans.  Should she be called out?

Does anyone seriously think the the Capital Group commissioned this study to inform themselves regardless of the conclusions? Whether they chose the authors because they were confident of getting the right answer or the authors bent their conclusions to fit their funder's interests is really irrelevant. Either way, its junk science with no credibility. Warren was right to call it out.

Putin has outplayed Obama in this game of checkers (Neither's strategy rises to the sophistication level of chess). We are watching two political failures make short sighted moves on the political board. Sadly, both countries will pay long term costs for allowing these two to the top. History will not be kind to either. The difference is that in the US, Obama's decisions are checked by established constitutional controls. In Russia, the Duma votes with 100% for the support of the great leader. The results will be terrible.

The strategy was incoherent because of Obama's penchant for rhetoric over results. In this particular case we had a plethora of equally unacceptable choices which Obama proceeded to sell, but in all fairness in the end there was nothing Obama could actually do.

We should stop bombing ISIS (it's ineffective anyhow), welcome Putin to the quagmire and withdraw from the field. There are plenty of Chechens in ISIS and plenty of Islamists in Russia. That plus the fact that Russia can't financially afford a war should keep Putin tied up for years and prevent anymore land grabs in Europe.
Some are good neighbors and then some are just ill-mannered, inconsiderate louts

@ Tim Kane - Tim could you first explain that line about Swedes being 1st to poke their nose into the conflict (my Gmail at my blog).

Then may I note an ironic twist. You note that the "West" is learning how to get energy from renewables and I agree that if the entire West could do that we (USA) might finally free ourselves from our major ally Saudi Arabia. But the country in the "West" that moves all too slowly toward renewables is the USA. Sweden provides one of several examples for the USA as concerns renewables but you will never learn that in the Times of fracking fanatics Nocera and Brooks.

Not sure why you threw that last line in about the Kurds. The relationships in the triangle Turkey-USA-Kurdistan are so complex that one hardly knows where the USA stands in that triangle.
Only-NeverInSweden.blogspot.com

@ Tim - This connects to your and my reply last line about Kurds in Turkey. There has just been a reported horrifying bombing in I believe the Kurdish part of Turkey. If so then who were the targets and who were the bumbers. And whose side is the US on in precisely that area? My Kurdish friends, all from just over the border in Iraqi Kurdistan, tell me that every offer of help from the USA is a two-edged sword and I believe them

1
The MidEast looks like Central Europe during the 30 years war. There's the balkanized Holy Roman Empire. There's the outsiders, serially poking their nose into the conflict: 1st the Swedes, then the French.

Mutual fatigue ended the 30 years war: very long/complex negotiations ieven while the war went on.

2
Meanwhile the source of religious radicalism are nations on the flanks of the conflict: Saudi Arabia & Iran. In a sense its a proxy war between regional powers. Meanwhile the strongest military in the region, the Israelis, sit anxiously watching events unfold. The best thing for them is that other parties keep bloodying themselves while they keep their powder dry and their treasury whole & full.

3
Our interests in the region are the integrity and stability of Turkey & Israel, and the flow of oil.

Oil today is like Sugar in the 18th century. It was the richest commodity and made for ugly social system but wealth in the Caribbean and much war/intrigue there. Then around 1800 Europeans learned how to extract sugar from beats and the value of the Caribbean collapsed quickly.

Today the West is learning how to get their energy from renewables at increasingly competitive prices. Once the developing world follows the developed world and shirks fossil fuels, the mid-east will go back to being a backwater with massive demographic& ideological problems.

Israel still faces a nasty demographic problem. Turkey an ethnic (Kurds) and possibly a political-religious ideology problem.

Back in October 1946, as the curtain was falling on the British Empire in India, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, to-be first Prime Minister of India, wrote to Sir Olaf Caroe, the British Governor of the North West Frontier Province (the NWFP & surrounds have been the target of scores of US drone strikes in the past decade!):

"British officials in India should remember that India is dynamic today and her long past of suppression makes the people irritable and intolerant of those who are associated with this suppression. There is today a bubbling life in India observable even more in the common people than in the upper classes. This life often takes a wrong turn. Nevertheless it is the hope of India and any suppression of it is to do injury to India. In any event it cannot be suppressed. This fact has to be recognised and people adapt themselves to it."

The British officers of that day no doubt thought they had objective reasons to think that the people who would succeed them because of the revolution - shaking free of British rule - lacked the intellectual tools to even hold the country together, let alone keep a democracy. Similarly, now, as Aatish Taseer and his class of St. Stephens and Oxford educated are swept into the dustbin of history, their skepticism is vastly apparent. There is no Nehru - so disdained today! - to tell them that this energy of the common people is the hope of India, and that it should not be suppressed or injured.
Your particular version of freedom, i.e. freedom without responsibility, is quite scary.

"The English language has caused a great loss to the country. We are losing our language, our culture as there are hardly any people who speak Sanskrit"

This is an actual quote from Indian Secretary of Interior (Home Ministry). His son was educated in UK while his daughter worked in US. I am not exactly sure if both are well versed in Sanskrit.

Looks like those who have already got to the riches or migrated away wants to impose their belief's on those left behind and take away the same tools that helped them climb the social ladder's.

No one is saying that only those people (in the Indian context) who are fluent in English are good at what they do and that the rest are idiots. But the ability to communicate ideas, thoughts, and feelings, gets a lot harder across language barriers. That may not matter too much in certain fields with limited working vocabularies, but is key in other fields (like the one I work in, software development.) Misunderstanding can result in the failure of a project, and at the very least, introduce a lot of overhead and reduce productivity. This especially applies to a situation where someone speaks broken or grammatically incorrect English but (mistakenly) thinks that their English is good enough; miscommunication occurs leading to issues and delayed deliveries.

Referring back to the article, language was just one issue that Aatish was referring to. The bigger problem is that much of the underprivileged people of India get very little education at all, in English or an Indian language, even if they go to schools (severely underfunded with high rates of teacher absenteeism). The best of these people acquire a lot of street-smartness to overcome their backgrounds and rise high in the political system, but it does not necessarily give them the judgment or wisdom to manage societies or countries.

And there are far too many influential people who confuse knowledge of English with ability and education. Some wisdom finally graced Indian billionaire Kumar Mangalam Birla, who confessed: "...Ironically, before we became more international, I used to be much more impressed by someone who could speak the Queen's English than, say, a chartered accountant from Jodhpur whose spoken English required some effort to understand.  Now when I look across all our operations in places like Brazil or Egypt or Thailand, I see a whole host of people who aren't comfortable in English, who need interpreters, but who are very, very good at what they do.  Sadly, it took that experience for me to respect an accountant from Rajasthan—my home state—as much as a graduate of St. Stephen's in Delhi.  At one time we even wanted to run English classes for some of our employees!  Now it's not an issue in my mind.  If you can get your point across, if you are adding value, if you are competent, then bloody hell to your English."
Yep, Drakes Cakes of Brooklyn (now owned by some conglomerate) brought us Ring Dings, Devil Dogs and Yodels.  I miss them all dearly.

.
I personally felt that Yodels were a thing you had a fling with, long or short, with no regrets about the start or about the end.

Ring Dings and Devil Dogs, however, were potential lifemates, like a Hostess Cupcake. I'm not saying I specifically formed lifelong relationships with any of them; but I can see that potential in them.

The only item in this category whose longevity I ever heard about was the Twinkie. Word around the school was that it would. not go stale for centuries. No idea why the same was not said about the Devil Dog, e.g.
I had devil dogs at first, then  RING DINGS, then ding dongs, then make to RING DINGS, and then a sugar high.  I was also happy to see the poet laureate of television make an appearance.
Tough puzzle. Good for Saturday when we expect them tough. Dingdongs before RINGDINGS. I've never heard of them. Must be an East Coast thing.  Nice to see NIPSEY Russell get mentioned.

All of the comments on this piece and the others of the same Russia/Syria conflict calling out Obama's "failure" and saying that now Putin is doing what we should've been doing are really disturbing.  What is Russia doing?  What is the end game?  And do you actually think it will be achieved?  Let me help--no.  And going heavier into a conflict just to prove to another country how tough we are is juvenile, short sighted and weak.  And of course it seems to be all men making these comments.  They probably all have monogrammed measuring sticks.
The fabric of a dream.

I am Russian, no secret. If I read this media it means that there are no restrictions about what a person can read or watch. Most world media have their web-sites in Russian like BBC, Reuters, DW, Euronews. More you read, better information you get and can analyze the events. The fact is - there are no moderate rebels there. Since nobody so far has given us some information about FSA taking actions against ISIS and controlling a territory. There is only ONE army with ONE command - SAA. Syrian Arab Army. Now, the SAA intelligence gives coordinates for the strongholds, warehouses, etc to the air support. It takes minutes for the jets or helicopters to arrive and support the ground troops that clean the area after the strikes. No bombing without a ground support can me any good. You can waste 1mln USD rocket to blow up a pick-up truck that costs 5 thousand USD. Now the only way for any what you call moderate rebel is to join efforts with SAA. Those who fire at SAA are the enemies. Period. SAA already taking back a lot of land and strategic-important heights. Turkey is screaming because SAA cuts the supply for ISIS from Turkey + Turks can not fly now and bomb their old enemies - Kurds. Turkey is letting big groups of the ISIS go to Syria armed. There was even a BBC film about one man who has been buying vests and other equipment and drove it from Belgium to Syria to support the holy fighters. The truth is terrible there.

Yes, and it doesn't matter how big Russia's eventual military failure may be. The Russian people will never know because they will have only the glowing reports of the Putin-controlled media to guide them. Any journalist that dares to report the truth will be silenced by any means necessary.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_journalists_killed_in_Russia

Looks like Russian "internet marketers" are active in these forums. Lest it be forgotten Putin is yet another in a long line of Russian authoritarian strongmen sitting atop a corrupt regime. I suspect the above informs much written about Russia in the free media.

Putin has overplayed his hand, largely for internal political purposes. Its unlikely Russia will have any significant impact in Syria other than to prolong a terrible war. Russia is attacking moderate rebels, not ISIS.
We had boots on the ground earlier in Iraq and Afghanistan and lost both war. Our military is inept. They are incapable of winning a war though they can kill hundreds of thousands on a whim.
The most popular leader in the world always digs his own grave? No, it's Obama who is going down, not Putin.
We are at war here in our Country.  We are seeing the demise of the Republican Party and America is about to come tumbling down.
Where indeed? It's been a long time.
Actually, the Sunni/Shi'a strife was created around 650 AD; but our meddling in the Middle East from 1953 onward has exacerbated it.
And we won't support the Peshmerga because they have been banned as a "terrorist organization."  Logical, no?
When they can make money selling the reports to the gullible.

Blessed!
Swift victory we all pray.
Tons of good Syrians in Egypt are hoping
to return to Damascus and Latvia.

USA should depart from Syria.
They did enough damage.
Arming the rebels to oust a leader.
The story of Obama regime.
And all recorded when he proclaimed his
plan for the "Arab Spring" and hope to
mold the world into his immoral

Wait until they devalue the dollar.
I have shed all tears for USA.
Nations rise... Nations fall.

Pray for victory.
Beheadings of innocent humans is most atrocious and the battle is to be won!

Keep the leader and submit to authority.
Chaos is always result of rebellion.

It's time we accept the fact that we cannot play it both ways. We cannot on the one hand engage ISIS and at the same time push for the removal of Assad, as bad as he may be, such a vacuum will not be fillable.  Now that Russia is entered the theater, arming secular moderate groups will not only not succeed, but prolong the war, further destabilize the country and cause more unimaginable suffering to the Syrian people. Syria, because of it's longstanding relationship with Russia, is a natural battleground for two old cold war rivals, and I believe that some of those calling for Assad's removal really just want to stick a thumb in Mr. Putin's eye in the spirit of rivalry. Sure Assad will commit atrocities if we wins back his power, but he may also be coerced into an amnesty deal. Given all the horrible choices, perhaps this is the best we can expect. If we oppose Russia in Syria today, as we did in Afghanistan in the 1990's, will end up with another Afghanistan? Do we detest Russia so much that we would provide arms to anybody willing to take them on? Are we doomed to repeat our mistakes?
